verses.text: At that time, some people came and told Jesus about the Galileans whose blood Pilate had mixed with their sacrifices.
verses.comment: This verse refers to a notorious incident in Jesus's time, showing Roman oppression and the suffering of innocent people. The mention of sacrifices is significant for understanding the context of temple worship.

verses.text: He answered them, 'Do you think those Galileans were worse sinners than all the other Galileans because they suffered this way?'
verses.comment: Jesus rejects the idea that suffering is always a direct punishment for personal sin. Instead, He calls for self-examination and repentance.

verses.text: No, I tell you; but unless you repent, you will all perish as they did.
verses.comment: Jesus emphasizes the universal need for repentance rather than focusing on the misfortunes of others.

verses.text: Or those eighteen who died when the tower in Siloam fell on them—do you think they were more guilty than everyone else living in Jerusalem?
verses.comment: The 'tower in Siloam' incident is unique to Luke and highlights the unpredictable nature of suffering.

verses.text: No, I tell you; but unless you repent, you will all perish as they did.
verses.comment: Repeating His earlier warning underscores the seriousness and universality of the call to repentance.

verses.text: And He told this parable: 'A man had a fig tree planted in his vineyard, and he came looking for fruit on it but found none.'
verses.comment: The fig tree often symbolizes Israel throughout the Old Testament, and the vineyard represents God's people.

verses.text: 'So he said to the vineyard worker, “Look, for three years I have been coming to seek fruit on this fig tree and haven’t found any. Cut it down. Why should it take up the soil?”'
verses.comment: Three years often symbolizes a period of reasonable expectation. The call to 'cut it down' is a threat of judgment that echoes prophetic warnings.

verses.text: 'But the worker replied, “Sir, leave it alone for one more year, and I will dig around it and put manure on it.”'
verses.comment: The vineyard worker’s intercession reflects Christ’s mercy and patience toward humanity, granting an extra period for repentance.

verses.text: 'If it bears fruit next year, well and good; but if not, you can cut it down.'
verses.comment: The expectation for fruit mirrors God's desire for our lives to reflect spiritual transformation.

verses.text: Now He was teaching in one of the synagogues on the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Jesus often taught in synagogues, showing His reverence for established worship and tradition.

verses.text: And there was a woman there who had been disabled by a spirit for eighteen years; she was bent over and could not straighten herself at all.
verses.comment: The description links physical suffering with spiritual affliction, a common ancient understanding.

verses.text: When Jesus saw her, He called her over and said, 'Woman, you are freed from your disability.'
verses.comment: Jesus’s authority to heal with a word highlights divine power and compassion.

verses.text: Then He laid His hands on her, and immediately she stood up straight and glorified God.
verses.comment: The laying on of hands foreshadows the sacramental actions later practiced in the early church. Her response is one of worship.

verses.text: But the synagogue leader, indignant that Jesus had healed on the Sabbath, said to the crowd, 'There are six days for work. So come and be healed on those days, not on the Sabbath day.'
verses.comment: The synagogue leader’s reaction highlights the tension between law and mercy, tradition and the new life Jesus brings.

verses.text: But the Lord answered him, 'You hypocrites! Each of you unties his ox or donkey from the stall on the Sabbath and leads it to water.'
verses.comment: Jesus appeals to common sense and compassion, revealing the true spirit of the law.

verses.text: 'Should not this woman, a daughter of Abraham whom Satan bound for eighteen years, be set free from this bondage on the Sabbath day?'
verses.comment: Setting this woman free on the Sabbath showcases Christ’s authority over spiritual oppression and His divine prerogative to restore.

verses.text: When He said this, all His opponents were ashamed, but the whole crowd was rejoicing at all the glorious things He was doing.
verses.comment: The crowd’s response is one of joyful recognition of God’s work, hinting at the proper communal response to miracles and grace.

verses.text: Then Jesus said, 'What is the kingdom of God like? To what can I compare it?'
verses.comment: Jesus begins a pair of parables comparing the nature and growth of God's kingdom.

verses.text: 'It is like a mustard seed that a man took and planted in his garden. It grew and became a tree, and the birds of the air made nests in its branches.'
verses.comment: The mustard seed parable emphasizes the hidden growth of God's reign, with Old Testament echoes of the messianic tree providing shelter for the nations.

verses.text: Again He asked, 'To what shall I compare the kingdom of God?'
verses.comment: A second parable invites meditation on the mystery and diffusion of the kingdom.

verses.text: 'It is like yeast that a woman took and mixed into about sixty pounds of flour until it was all leavened.'
verses.comment: Yeast permeating the dough represents the silent yet total transformation of the world through the kingdom.

verses.text: And He went through towns and villages, teaching as He journeyed toward Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Jesus’s purposeful journey sets up His final mission, underscoring the importance of Jerusalem in salvation history.

verses.text: Someone asked Him, 'Lord, are only a few going to be saved?' He said to them,
verses.comment: The question about salvation shows perennial human concern about exclusivity and access to God.

verses.text: 'Strive to enter through the narrow door, for many, I tell you, will seek to enter and will not be able.'
verses.comment: The metaphor of a 'narrow door' alludes to the necessity of grace and perseverance, echoing themes of self-examination and authentic transformation.

verses.text: 'Once the master of the house gets up and shuts the door, you will begin to stand outside and knock, saying, “Lord, open to us.” But He will answer, “I don’t know you or where you come from.”'
verses.comment: Jesus warns that opportunity does not last forever. Being known by the Lord is foundational.

verses.text: 'Then you will say, “We ate and drank in your presence, and you taught in our streets.”'
verses.comment: Merely external association with Jesus is not sufficient; deeper communion is required.

verses.text: 'But He will answer, “I tell you, I don’t know you or where you come from; depart from me, all you workers of evil!”'
verses.comment: The rejection uses strong Old Testament imagery about separation from God because of sin.

verses.text: 'There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth, when you see Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, but you yourselves thrown out.'
verses.comment: This verse acknowledges the continuity of God's covenant people and the reality of exclusion for the unfaithful.

verses.text: 'People will come from east and west, and from north and south, and will sit down at the feast in the kingdom of God.'
verses.comment: The universal invitation to the feast in God’s kingdom echoes Old Testament visions of a global gathering, which underpins the church’s mission.

verses.text: 'And behold, some who are last will be first, and some who are first will be last.'
verses.comment: This reversal speaks to God’s grace and the mystery of election; it invites humility and hope.

verses.text: At that very hour some Pharisees came and said to Him, 'Leave and go somewhere else, for Herod wants to kill you.'
verses.comment: Herod’s threat highlights the mounting danger surrounding Jesus, foreshadowing His coming Passion.

verses.text: He replied, 'Go and tell that fox, “I cast out demons and perform healings today and tomorrow, and on the third day I finish my work.”'
verses.comment: Jesus refers to His miracles and impending completion, using 'third day' language as an allusion to His resurrection—a subtle declaration of divine authority.

verses.text: 'But I must go on my way today, tomorrow, and the next day, for it cannot be that a prophet should perish outside Jerusalem.'
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s prophetic history sees her rejecting God’s messengers—pointing to Jesus’s self-understanding as the final and greatest prophet.

verses.text: 'Jerusalem, Jerusalem, who kills the prophets and stones those sent to her! How often I have longed to gather your children together as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you were not willing.'
verses.comment: Jesus reveals His longing and maternal care for Jerusalem, echoing divine compassion and protection—strong christological indicator of Jesus’s divine prerogatives and His heart for unity.

verses.text: 'See, your house is left to you desolate. And I say to you, you will not see Me until you say, “Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord.”'
verses.comment: Jesus foretells the judgment and points to future recognition of His messianic identity—an implicit claim to be the awaited Lord of the sanctuary.
